Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Consortium at the 18th International Symposium on Robotics Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal partially supports U.S. Ph.D. students working in robotics travel costs to attend a Doctoral Consortium at the International Symposium on Robotics Research (ISRR). ISRR, which in 2017 is held in Puerto Varas, Chile, is one of the oldest and most prestigious symposia on robotics, bringing together top researchers from around the world to discuss technological breakthroughs and the roles and status of robotics in society. Supported participants will be able to present their own research to eminent researchers, receive mentoring from them, and have opportunities to network with fellow robotics researchers. Special efforts will be made to include students from under-represented groups and from institutions with fewer opportunities to participate in such a venue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2017 International Symposium on Robotics Research (ISRR) supported a highly successful doctoral consortium program supported by NSF and industry funding. This program allowed US-based graduate students to travel to the symposium and participate in the program. The doctoral consoritium included a total of 32 participants, of which 21 were US-based students supported from NSF funds. Participants were recruited from the pool of accepted papers at ISRR 2017, and were expected to participate for the entire symposium as well as a day-long international workshop in Santiago following ISRR. 

As part of the program, each doctoral consortium participant was matched to a senior member of the community prior to arrival. The senior mentors were chosen to be compatible with the student’s interest, and were responsible for providing feedback to their mentees on their presentations during the symposium. Mentors and mentees also participated in a special doctoral consortium lunch where they had a chance to engage in more focused 1-1 interactions.

Each of the doctoral consortium participants will have a paper that will appear in an edited volume of symposium proceedings, and several are co-authors on a special issue of the International Symposium of Robotics Research which will appear in early Spring, 2019.
